newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Ivorian president vows EU cocoa fat fight.
newsitem.headline: Ivorian president vows EU cocoa fat fight.

text.p: Ivorian President Henri Konan Bedie has told visiting French confectioners to unite against a European Union proposal which would allow wider use of non-cocoa fats in chocolate.

"We must protect chocolate in its purest form," he told French chefs visiting ahead of France's 6th Festival International du Chocolat planned for Abidjan in February 1998. "That is, without blends. Without vegetable fats," he said.
Ivory Coast is the world's top cocoa producer and exporter.
European Union plans under review would allow manufacturers to use up to five percent of non-cocoa fats in chocolate, a move viewed by producers as a threat to export demand.
Bedie was speaking as a week of factory and plantation visits by the French delgation ended on Friday -- when his comments were broadcast on state television.
Ivorian commodities minister Guy-Alain Gauze opposed use of non-cocoa fats move during a world food standards review last October at the Geneva-based Codex Alimentarius.

The world chocolate manufacturers forum, Office International du Cacoa, du Chocolat et de la Confiserie, visiting Ivory Coast in early June, said ageing consumer country populations and perception of chocolate as an unhealthy product posed a far greater threat to the cocoa sector.
